title: How to Clean the Heating Element in a Grill

methods.name: Cleaning Tubes in a Gas Grill

steps.headline: Disconnect your fuel.
steps.description: Make sure your propane or other gas supply is completely turned off before you begin. You may even choose to disconnect the gas tank after turning off the fuel for extra safety. Do not attempt to clean your grill while gas is connected or while it is still hot. This not only means making sure that your grill is off, but that you turn the valve on your gas tank to cut off the flow of gas to the grill.

steps.headline: Scrape the grate.
steps.description: Before you clean the burner tubes in your gas grill, you probably want to clean off the grate. Removing burnt material from the grate will lessen the amount of debris and ash falling down onto your clean tubes. Use a steel wool pad or a wire brush to clean off your grates. Many grill tool kits even come with a brush and scraper. Use the scraper tip to help dislodge stubborn chunks.

steps.headline: Clean the burner covers with soap and water.
steps.description: The triangular-shaped covers, otherwise known as flame tamers, heat tents, or vaporizer bars, can be removed and wiped down with a wire brush followed by a wet cloth. If you find covers that are particularly charred, though, remove them and rinse them in a sink or bucket with dish soap and warm water after brushing. Submerge the covers in the soapy water and scrub with a steel wool pad or a scrubby sponge. Then rinse the covers with clean, running water and dry them with a towel.

steps.headline: Scrub the burner with a wire brush.
steps.description: While the burner covers are still off, scrub your burners with a wire brush, paying particular attention to the small holes where the gas comes out, otherwise known as the port area. Then, use a damp sponge and warm water to wipe away any remaining debris. This should be done with your burners in place in the grill.

steps.headline: Scrape out the bottom and the drip pan.
steps.description: After cleaning the heating elements of your grill, a lot of carbon and debris will fall down to the bottom. Use your wire brush to sweep away what you can. If there is a lot of debris at the bottom, you may even want to use a shop vac to help you get it all out. Take this time to empty the drip pan on your grill, too. Remove the grease and scrape it into a can for disposal, then rinse out the pan. Do not pour the grease down any sinks or drains, though, as it may create a block in your pipes.

steps.headline: Reassemble your grill.
steps.description: Once all of the individual elements have been cleaned, you can reassemble your grill. Replace the drip pan, burner covers, and grate, and you are ready to grill again. Remember to repeat the cleaning process every one to three months, depending upon how often you use your grill, and always clean it out before the start of your grilling season.

steps.headline: Unplug the grill and let it cool.
steps.description: Before cleaning an electric grill, make sure it is completely unplugged, any secondary electric sources are disconnected, and allow the grill to cool. Do not attempt to clean it before it’s cool enough to touch with your bare hands.

steps.headline: Scrape away any char from the plates.
steps.description: You can use a scraper that came with your grill or a scrubby sponge  to scrape down both grill plates. Once the debris is dislodged, wipe it up with a damp paper towel and throw it away. Do not use wire brushes or steel wool, as these could damage the grill’s non-stick surface.

steps.headline: Wipe down the plates with a soapy sponge.
steps.description: Using a sponge soaked in wet, soapy water and wrung out, wipe down the plates of the grill. Then, rinse away the soap using a clean damp sponge or a paper towel. Be sure to keep your drip tray at the front base of your grill to catch any excess water before it spreads to any electrical elements. Avoid getting water on plugs, controls, cords, and other electrical components.

steps.headline: Dry the plates.
steps.description: Once you have wiped off the heating plates, dry them with a clean, soft towel or paper towel. Allow them to further air-dry for several minutes after wiping them down. Do not plug the grill in for use until the plates have dried completely.

steps.headline: Wash your scraper and drip tray.
steps.description: Most electric grills come with scrapers and drip trays that can be washed in the dishwasher. However, if you do not have access to a dishwasher, you can hand wash them using dish soap and hot water. Rinse them with clean water and allow them to dry completely before using them again.

steps.headline: Clean out the charcoal.
steps.description: In the case of a charcoal grill, the charcoal, itself, is the heating element. Once the charcoal has completely cooled, remove any remaining large chunks by hand. Then, open up the ash catcher at the base of the grill and allow the ash to drain out into a container such as a box or trash bag. You may want to use gloves while you remove charcoal chunks from your grill. Once you have drained all the ash out of the catcher, scrape down the side of the grill to remove any additional stuck-on ash and debris. Allow this to drain out before closing off the catcher. Even if you do not scrape your grate down every time you grill, you should remove ashes after every grill session to keep your grill clean and keep your fires manageable while you cook.

steps.headline: Leave the char in place between grilling sessions.
steps.description: Your charcoal grill doesn’t have a built-in heating element like a gas or electric grill. Subsequently, the char on your grill grates won’t flake off and clog your burners. Instead, leaving the char on actually helps protect your grates. Instead of cleaning your charcoal grill after you're done grilling, clean it immediately before your next grilling event.

steps.headline: Scrape off the grates.
steps.description: Using a wire brush or steel wool pad, scrape down your grates right before you are getting ready to heat up your grill. For stubborn spots, you can also wad up some aluminum foil and rub it against the grates to get off burnt-in food and large chunks.

text: Cleaning Tubes in a Gas Grill Disconnect your fuel. Make sure your propane or other gas supply is completely turned off before you begin. You may even choose to disconnect the gas tank after turning off the fuel for extra safety. Do not attempt to clean your grill while gas is connected or while it is still hot. This not only means making sure that your grill is off, but that you turn the valve on your gas tank to cut off the flow of gas to the grill. Scrape the grate. Before you clean the burner tubes in your gas grill, you probably want to clean off the grate. Removing burnt material from the grate will lessen the amount of debris and ash falling down onto your clean tubes. Use a steel wool pad or a wire brush to clean off your grates. Many grill tool kits even come with a brush and scraper. Use the scraper tip to help dislodge stubborn chunks. Clean the burner covers with soap and water. The triangular-shaped covers, otherwise known as flame tamers, heat tents, or vaporizer bars, can be removed and wiped down with a wire brush followed by a wet cloth. If you find covers that are particularly charred, though, remove them and rinse them in a sink or bucket with dish soap and warm water after brushing. Submerge the covers in the soapy water and scrub with a steel wool pad or a scrubby sponge. Then rinse the covers with clean, running water and dry them with a towel. Scrub the burner with a wire brush. While the burner covers are still off, scrub your burners with a wire brush, paying particular attention to the small holes where the gas comes out, otherwise known as the port area. Then, use a damp sponge and warm water to wipe away any remaining debris. This should be done with your burners in place in the grill. Scrape out the bottom and the drip pan. After cleaning the heating elements of your grill, a lot of carbon and debris will fall down to the bottom. Use your wire brush to sweep away what you can. If there is a lot of debris at the bottom, you may even want to use a shop vac to help you get it all out. Take this time to empty the drip pan on your grill, too. Remove the grease and scrape it into a can for disposal, then rinse out the pan. Do not pour the grease down any sinks or drains, though, as it may create a block in your pipes. Reassemble your grill. Once all of the individual elements have been cleaned, you can reassemble your grill. Replace the drip pan, burner covers, and grate, and you are ready to grill again. Remember to repeat the cleaning process every one to three months, depending upon how often you use your grill, and always clean it out before the start of your grilling season. Cleaning an Electric Grill Unplug the grill and let it cool. Before cleaning an electric grill, make sure it is completely unplugged, any secondary electric sources are disconnected, and allow the grill to cool. Do not attempt to clean it before it’s cool enough to touch with your bare hands. Scrape away any char from the plates. You can use a scraper that came with your grill or a scrubby sponge  to scrape down both grill plates. Once the debris is dislodged, wipe it up with a damp paper towel and throw it away. Do not use wire brushes or steel wool, as these could damage the grill’s non-stick surface. Wipe down the plates with a soapy sponge. Using a sponge soaked in wet, soapy water and wrung out, wipe down the plates of the grill. Then, rinse away the soap using a clean damp sponge or a paper towel. Be sure to keep your drip tray at the front base of your grill to catch any excess water before it spreads to any electrical elements. Avoid getting water on plugs, controls, cords, and other electrical components. Dry the plates. Once you have wiped off the heating plates, dry them with a clean, soft towel or paper towel. Allow them to further air-dry for several minutes after wiping them down. Do not plug the grill in for use until the plates have dried completely. Wash your scraper and drip tray. Most electric grills come with scrapers and drip trays that can be washed in the dishwasher. However, if you do not have access to a dishwasher, you can hand wash them using dish soap and hot water. Rinse them with clean water and allow them to dry completely before using them again. Clearing out a Charcoal Grill Clean out the charcoal. In the case of a charcoal grill, the charcoal, itself, is the heating element. Once the charcoal has completely cooled, remove any remaining large chunks by hand. Then, open up the ash catcher at the base of the grill and allow the ash to drain out into a container such as a box or trash bag. You may want to use gloves while you remove charcoal chunks from your grill. Once you have drained all the ash out of the catcher, scrape down the side of the grill to remove any additional stuck-on ash and debris. Allow this to drain out before closing off the catcher. Even if you do not scrape your grate down every time you grill, you should remove ashes after every grill session to keep your grill clean and keep your fires manageable while you cook. Leave the char in place between grilling sessions. Your charcoal grill doesn’t have a built-in heating element like a gas or electric grill. Subsequently, the char on your grill grates won’t flake off and clog your burners. Instead, leaving the char on actually helps protect your grates. Instead of cleaning your charcoal grill after you're done grilling, clean it immediately before your next grilling event. Scrape off the grates. Using a wire brush or steel wool pad, scrape down your grates right before you are getting ready to heat up your grill. For stubborn spots, you can also wad up some aluminum foil and rub it against the grates to get off burnt-in food and large chunks.
